38606788.review:
Of all the VR games I've played so far, this is by far the best VR experience. It's the first game I've played that has really brought out the visceral gut reactions to movement for me in VR - before playing this game, I'd thought I was immune to it. Let me tell you: I was wrong.

The flip side of that? This is also by far the most terrifying game I've played. Even though I can feel that I'm standing on solid ground, watching myself jumping across huge drops and knowing that if my aim is off or I miss the grab, I will fall... it's legitimately scary. The good news is that, the moment you realize you're going to fall, there's an emergency eject button that returns you to a solid location. But that doesn't stop it from being scary. My heart was racing trying to traverse some of the more perilous areas, but despite that - or, maybe, because of it - I predict that this is one of the VR games I will end up logging the most hours in. In short bursts...

And of course, aside from being a great VR experience, the game is also legitimately fun, and provides nice replay value with some exploration to fill your first couple of runs through each level, then a speed running challenge once you're more familiar with it.

36901806.review:
Ich habe noch nie eine Rückerstattung auf Steam beantragt. Keine Angst, auch für dieses Spiel nicht, aber nach den ersten paar Minuten war ich kurz davor. Das Tutorial ist nicht auf die Oculus Rift abgestimmt, die Controllerbelegung wird nur für die Vive angezeigt. Das Drehen der Sicht wollte nicht funktionieren (Ich habe nur ein 2-Sensor Setup)... Festhalten per Trigger- statt Grifftaste?! Ich hatte das Gefühl, als müsse man irgendwo noch einen Oculus Modus aktivieren können, so wie es etwa bei Space Pirate Trainer der Fall ist. Aber Nein, auch eine Suche half nicht weiter. Somit landete ich das erste mal auf einer Seite, die mir erklärte, wie Steam Rückerstattungen funktionieren. Aha, man darf für eine erfolgreiche Rückerstattung nicht mehr als 2h gespielt haben. Da ich bis jetzt nur einige Minuten gespielt hatte, dachte ich mir: "Was solls, probier es eben nochmal".

Vorher las ich mir allerdings im Forum durch, wie angeblich das Drehen der Ansicht funktionieren sollte.
Und - was soll ich sagen - nach etwas rumprobieren klappte es! Dafür muss in den Optionen allerdings der "Seated Mode" ativiert werden, was mir nicht ganz einleuchtete. Daraufhin kann die Ansicht mittels des rechten Thumbsticks oder durch gedrückthalten des A-Knopfes und "Ziehen" der Welt gedreht werden.

STEUERUNG:
Die Bewegung/Steuerung ist am Anfgang SEHR gewöhnungsbedürftig. Im Prinzip gibt es überall im Level verteilt blaue Flächen, an denen man sich festhalten kann. Wie bereits erwähnt geschieht dies per Trigger-Taste. Dies ist wohl daher gerechtfertigt, da es sich streng genommen nicht um ein Greifen, sondern um ein "Abschießen" der Hände handelt. Alle blauen Flächen innerhalb einer gewissen Reichweite können mit einer oder 2 Händen gefasst werden. Wenn beide Hände greifen und dann loslassen, springt der Charakter in die Richtung, in die man in diesem Moment schaut. Wenn man solche Sprünge schnell genug aneinanderkettet, springt man höher und schneller. Und das ist auch schon alles*.
Wenn man dieser Form der Bewegung eine Chance gibt, wird man sich wundern wie schnell man atemberaubende Sprungserien u.ä. hinbekommt. Hierzu gibt es zu sagen, dass ich lediglich am Anfang, als ich die Ansicht noch nicht drehen konnte Probleme mit Motion Sickness hatte. Ich bin auch eher anfällig dafür, bei Spielen aus der Ego-Perspektive, die keine Teleport-Option anbieten, ist bei mir normalerweise Schluss. Hier bin ich verwundert und weiß selbst nicht so recht, warum ich eigentlich nicht im Strahl kotze wenn ich durch die Luft springe und über Geländer rutsche. Aber hier funktioniert es wunderbar und macht super viel Spaß.

*Im Steam Forum habe ich gelesen dass wohl später noch ein Jetpack dazukommen wird, aber so weit in ich im Moment noch nicht.


LEVELDESIGN:
Man merkt, dass die Entwickler versucht haben viel Abwechslung in die Level zu bringen. Nahezu keine 2 Levels spielen im komplett selben Setting. Meiner Meinung nach hätte das garnicht unbedingt sein müssen. Ich hätte kein Problem damit 5-10 Level in der gleichen Umgebung mit unterschiedlichen Strecken zu spielen. Dagegen fällt hier so ein Level wie das Höhlenlevel total aus dem Raster.  Die sonstigen Level die ich gesspielt habe, waren grafisch eher einfach gehalten, mit einem Fokus auf einfachen, geometrischen Formen und kräftigen Farben. Dieser Look steht dem Spiel gut und erinnert an WipeOut , Ninja Warrior etc. 
Alles in Allem sollte die Kreativität der Entwickler aber positiv erwähnt werden. 
Schon allein das Roboterlevel hat mich sehr positiv überrascht.


tl;dr: Nach kurzer Eingewöhnungszeit ist das Spiel seinen Preis definitiv wert. Und da sonst Wave-Shooter und allgemein First-Person-Shooter bei VR vorherrschen, sollte man diesem Spiel erst Recht eine Chance geben, weil es viel anders, und das meiste richtig macht.

36650309.review:
So, this is my first review of any game, ever, but I feel like I should for this game because I was hoping for it to be THE game to play on my Rift. I played it for about an hour and refunded it. I played many of the easy levels and then a match of the multiplayer. I'll list some talking points below in no particular order.

Music: In my opinion, I didn't really care for it and I seemed to only hear the same three or four songs in my play time. I would love to be able to add my own music.

Gameplay: I feel like there's some conflicts with the games design. For instance, they emphasize that you should beat the levels as fast as possible but then they leave secrets to find in the level that you have to go out of your way to collect. The levels I played I rarely got a medal because I was exploring the level trying to find everything. Perhaps this is intended to make you replay levels. I'm not sure though because, as far as I can tell, there's no way to restart a level once you're in it. There also isn't a way to return to the main menu to select a different level or mode or anything. I had to take off my Rift, close the game, and reopen it just to get to the main menu. I tried every button on my controllers and nothing worked, which was midly annoying. One last tiny thing, I think in some levels the checkpoints were a bit too far apart, but a majority of them were fine.

Movement: Overall feels good enough. My biggest gripe is that I thought if you wanted to push yourself off a wall, for example, you'd have to actually push off with your arms like in Echo Arena. Instead, you merely grab a blue environment object with both hands, look where you want to go, and then release your hands. This is also true while you're in mid air, so if you want to look around while you're falling, you'll start moving in whatever direction your looking and could potentially mess up a jump. I wish I could use a movement stick to control where I go in the air. Now, I didn't check the settings, but it seems like there's no snap turning. I managed okay for the most part but there were times where I would've liked to snap turn. I know there's a button to reset orientation quickly, which is nice, but that requires me to take off my headset to see where I am, which cuts out time in this time racing game. The only times I felt a bit VR sick was from falling at great heights, but it was tolerable for me.

Visuals: Visually, this is a very nice looking game. One of the best looking ones, honestly. Very stylized. I like that you can get a sort of preview of the level as it loads in. No gripes here.

Customization: You can customize your character in this game and I was already happy with some of the first things you could choose from, which is greatly appreciated since many games with a "customize your character" feature make you look ugly at the start. You unlock new outfits and parts by just playing the game, completing levels and challenges. Nothing wrong here.

Multiplayer: So, when I first joined in there was a sign that said something like "work together to complete the level" when it was just a race. No cooperation involved. Felt akin to playing a surf map on Counter Strike. Left me a little dissappointed. The only time I felt any sort of "cooperation" was when I asked a guy about a part of the level I was struggling with. 

Despite my problems with the game, I still recommend it only because I feel the problems I have with it are somewhat personal (such as not liking the music). It runs well, plays well enough, and has a good concept.

36563375.review:
Disclaimer: I got this for free from a dev who was offering copies during a Giant Bomb stream.

TO THE TOP has been my favorite VR game for a while and continues to be every time I boot it up. It has incredibly satisfying and fun movement mechanics that evolve as you progress into more difficult levels that demand more precision, implement new obstacles, and introduce new methods of locomotion. The levels themselves are for the most part very well designed and varied both in gameplay and art design. I think the game is beautiful and some of the levels capture that sense of scale that's only possible in VR so well that they made my jaw drop.

I really enjoy that each level has a few different ways to get medals (five medals each: three different completion time goals, one medal for finding all of the geoms scattered throughout the level, and a hidden medal usually placed down a well-hidden side path). Collecting the geoms encourages you to give the level at least one slow playthrough, finding various paths and giving you a chance to practice the parts you struggle with. The hidden medal is incredibly satisfying to get, both in finding the path to it and actually executing on the usually very challenging platforming you must do to get to it. The completion time goals give you a reason to put to the test what you learned and practiced in your first few runs, and completing a level faster than the fastest challenge time is often incredibly satisfying. Each time I got to a new level I was excited to spend time at least attempting to get all five medals.

The soundtrack is also amazing and the vibe it has really adds to the excitement and joy of going through levels leaping, sliding, falling, skating, etc. The avatar customization options are a neat little incentive to keep trying for more medals and a lot of them look pretty cool.

If you have a VR headset and think you'd enjoy this even a little bit I'd say go for it, this game is a joy.

35981403.review:
This game feels like it couldn't decide whether it wanted an open world or a time trial game so it tried to make both. The movement system and being confined to the tiles the game lets you travel on makes it feel like a time trial game but then to get all the rewards you have to take it slow and explore the map. Free roaming sucks ass though because the game makes you travel along a set path. The watch with the music plater would fit perfectly in with an open world game but once again you're just following a path the developers set aside for you. Even the time trial portion isnt that good because getting a quick run comes down to "I hope the game understands what I'm trying to grab onto. There are checkpoints everywhere meaning that you don't feel like you lose a lot of progress if you mess up but to get the first two medals its braindead easy, meaning that you won't ever need the checkpoints, while the third and final medal is so difficult to get you won't have time to use checkpoints. They're pointless. 

The music is good though so thanks for the $25 radio.

This game is absolutely amazing. First level, I have a thril and a grin. Second level, I find a flow for a moment on a giant tower and a laugh and smile like a goofball.

Third level, I dive headlong into the flow of the movement fighting for nearly impossible leaps laughing like a maniac.
I finished the first ten levels. I had awful times on some, but incredible fun every time.

35607042.review:
I've seen a lot of climbing VR experiences and always shrugged them off.  Nothing there that caught my attention.  Then comes along TO THE TOP.  A competitive in nature climbing sim that is as fun as it is addicting.  The climbing mechanics are very fluid and responsive, the pace at which you can move is exhillerating, you've collectibles to find that unlock customizable skins, and to top it off you have a leaderboard that you can race against to claim top spot in the ranks.  One thing it lacks and I'm hoping for an addition of in the future is the ability to play co-op.  You can either race your friend to the goal or play a sort of cooperative mode where you require your friend to lend you a hand (literally) or there's a mechanism only one of you can reach and activate in order for the other to move on.  

Best climbing VR sim to date!

35230599.review:
If you're on Oculus you need a third camera or the screen will keep going blue when you turn around. But even then, it's not great. 

(Update: some clarification of issues I had not related to it being difficult to play in 180 degree tracking). 

I found the sudden stop when you touch the ground to be a little unpleasant. The camera moves too quickly when grabbing onto surfaces and changing between using one or both hands. I understand the camera needs to update quickly to show your new position, and maybe there's a reason behind this to reduce motion sickness, but for me it felt jerky. The colour scheme, particularly in the early levels, is not great. I should say that there are many positives to the game, not least of all the fact that it feels a lot more complete than other vr 'experiences'. But until I get a third camera, I won't be playing it again. After that I will give it another go and see if being able to play uninterrupted will balance out the negatives I had with the experience.

In this mode you can use either the joystick to rotate or use a method called 'grab turning' to rotate

35108681.review: It's been a VERY long time since a game has given me so much visceral, unadulterated, joy just from a core mechanic. As with most VR titles, it's hard to convey the exact evolutions and experience; but this game truly conveys the superhero/urban explorer sensation of jumping from ledge to ledge and flying through the air.  To The Top is masterfully crafted, the environments are begging to be explored, the music fits like a glove to the gameplay, the leading curve is easy but you'll constantly push yourself to get better at it. When you find a secret area, you really feel like you're exploring outside the bounds of the world (even though you're not). Granted this is something I've done countless times in other games, but feeling that way with your own body is something else entirely. I find myself wanting to spend more and more time listening to the soundtrack and interesting myself in there environments and what usually stops me is there octagonal exhaustion of constantly swinging my arms around to leap from building to building. Very happy with this purchase and it's quickly becoming my favorite VR title.

34745139.review:
When I fired this up, for 15 mins or so I thought I had made a mistake in getting it. I was about to consign this one to a refund but you quickly begin to see what this is all about. Jumping around massive environments really fast is a lot of fun!

This really is one of the rare VR games which I actually consider to be 'complete' and does something different. Well worth £15, especially when you consider the amount of crap there is out there for VR at the moment for much more money.

In my opinon, this jump/look mechanic is the best for movement in VR. It feels extremely fluid (compared to teleport which I find clunky) and I didn't feel any motion sickness when jumping around, which is 95% of the game. That said, if you're *very* sensitive, it may not agree with you. I'd recommend trying it and you'll know in a short period of time whether you'll be okay.

8.5/10

障害物から障害物へ！建物から建物へ！
まるで映画のスパイダーマンのような体験ができるゲームです。

操作も簡単且直感的で、チュートリアルステージもあるので安心です＾＾

最初酔いやすそうだな～なんて思ってましたが、そんなことはありませんでした。
普通に長時間酔わずにプレイできました＾＾
ただ慣れないとチェックポイントの移動だけはウッ！てなります。

タイムアタックはベタですがやはりこの手のゲームの場合、燃えますね！
クリアタイムによって所謂金、銀、銅の三段階評価が用意されており、
上級者用のタイムは最初は「無理だろｗｗｗ」とか思いますがゲームに慣れて、コツをつかむと達成できたりなどして、そのへんの難易度調整も絶妙でモチベが保てます。

マップのいたるところに散りばめられているので、マップを縦横無尽に駆け回って探す楽しさもあります。
さらに宝探しとは別に隠し通路探しというのもあります。
こちらは宝探しとは違い、マップのどこかに隠されているのでそれをみつけ、さらにその隠し通路を攻略しなきゃならないというRPGでいう二週目のやり込み要素みたいな感じもあります。

ただ、中盤あたりからステージが複雑かつ自由度がましてきて、
マップによっては道に迷ってイライラしますね(笑)
せめて簡単な矢印ナビくらいあると嬉しかったかも。

33920035.review:
Two Minutes In:  Hey, this is kinda neat.  I can jump and stuff.  Kinda scared of falling, though...

Ten Minutes In:  I'M A FREAKIN' SUPERHERO!  WOOOOOOOO!

The premise of the game is that you are training to be a superhero, and it absolutely nails that feeling.  You start off stumbling and awkward, nervously leaping across gaps and trying not to look down.  By the end of the "easy" levels, you're screaming through levels like an adrenaline-fueled hypervelocity chimpanzee and treating gravity as a minor nuisance that sometimes gets in the way of your craziest stunts.

The controls hit that coveted sweet spot of "easy to learn, hard to master".  The game introduces new mechanics at a reasonable pace, mixed in with clever and unique level design that forces you to adjust your climbing strategy on the fly.  You can take your time exploring stages to find every last little secret, or attempt to blast through the levels at warp speed.

One side note - this game initially scared me off because I have motion sickness issues.  Surprisingly, I've been able to handle it very well with minimal issues.  I wouldn't make this the first VR game you play, but don't be afraid to give it a try.

I have had my Vive for about 3 months at this point. I have splurged on about 75 games. I have Gorn. I have Onward. I have Form. I have SUPERHOT. I have a ton of great games. I have enjoyed hundreds of hours in VR. 

Nothing compares to TO THE TOP

This may be the best game I've played in ~20+ years of gaming.

The music. The controls. The visuals. It all comes together in an incredible way here. I hear the music in my head everywhere I go. I close my eyes and I'm flying through the air,

Nothing compares to the feeling of flying through one of these levels, aiming for that top speed medal, hitting every jump to the beat. Unbelievable. 

This is a truly complete VR experience. At this price level I was blown away by the first third of the campaign. Then it gets fucking crazy. Then it gets even CRAZIER. 

There's hours and hours of content here and it just keeps getting better. 

Every person with a VR headset should own this game.

33656061.review:
I've only put and hour or so into the game so far, but it's already earned its price tag.  For a "simple" control scheme, the devs have really gone all out on how diverse the levels are.  I just did my first run through of a very Mirror's Edge-inspired level, complete with solar panels, skyscrapers and construction cranes.

While perseverance will get you through a level, it won't get you any of the medals you'll need to progress.  The levels are very much intended to be learned, then memorized, then exploited to hit the fastest time medal.  Every level has several routes, and usually the most obvious route is not the optimal one.  These levels are HUGE, and only seem to keep increasing in size.  Recently I'd worried that I was becoming immune to VR's biggest feature: presence.  I no longer flinch away from robots in Raw Data, Brookhaven isn't scary.  TTT has my palms sweating every time I play it, which hasn't happened, ever.   The fear of falling combined with the fear of screwing up a set of especially tricky jumps to get a hidden geom, cranks up the experience to levels I haven't experienced in other games.

The graphics are ok...like a lower budget Mirror's Edge, TTT uses color coding for you to understand the world.  It feels like the devs may have been a bit overly stingy with their polygon count, but the sheer size of these levels likely demands it.  The art style is consistent and pleasant, and free of overly showy distractions.  Like Awaken, theyre doing the best they can with the budget (monetary and vr-framerate) they've got.

Oh and the soundtrack is a nice pleasant surprise, with lots of actual SONGS, not just some repetitive techno beat.  It's an unfortunately small song list, but it's a much better effort than I've heard in ANYTHING else.

33296921.review:
It's very easy to look at the media available for this game and wonder why it exists when Climbey is already around, but to make that comparison and write the game off because of it is to do yourself a huge disservice. TO THE TOP is an excellent platforming game that's less about pinpoint precision and intense climbing action and more of a high-speed parkour game where exploration and speedrunning are both equally rewarded.

The controls feel a little unintuitive at first and until you get a real feel for the mechanics, it can be difficult to see the appeal, but as soon as you adjust you're guaranteed to have a moment where the game just clicks and you're launching yourself from jump to jump in an incredibly smooth and exciting way.

The level design is absolutely fantastic and the developers have found a lot of ways to throw new challenges your way without ever detracting from the core gameplay. While I personally like to go through levels as quickly as possible without stopping or restarting, there's a ton of different routes and alternate areas to explore in each level that you'll have a lot of content to play through before you're completely done with the game.

Couple all this with a superb soundtrack and a minimalist yet effective graphical style and it's absolutely an experience worth checking out.

[h1]A leaping good time[/h1]
[b]A combat free game about leaping more so than climbing through 30 different levels in VR[/b]. I have to say I'm quite impressed by the amount of joy that can be had with soaring through the virtual air. It's little to nothing to watch but experiencing it is a whole different story.

+Amazing gorgeous worlds and levels

+Make me feel like a parquor master
+Your hands extend off your controllers so you don't have to reach

-Some issues with in game wrist menu

-A little pricy compared to some other VR games

Be warned though that if you at all have trouble with balance or have a fear of hights then this game might be a bit much to take in. If tossing yourself off a crane in hopes that you catch yourself on another crane doesn't appeal to you then maybe skip this one?

If I can leave you with anything to convince you to buy I'll say that every single person I've had try this game hasn't wanted to stop once they start.

Must have

Avoid

33003246.review:
I'm frankly amazed this game has not gotten more attention yet, because To The Top is exactly the breath of fresh air that VR needs right now. 

Moving around is less about 'Climbing' and more about 'Leapfrogging' from one hold to the next. Along the ground, the feeling is similar to pulling yourself along with skipoles. The momentum you have and direction you fling yourself determines your leap's initial trajectory, but by looking towards where you want to go, you are granted a modest degree of air control. This 'perfectly-imperfect' amount of control helps keep things from getting too easy. The game then does a good job of gradually introducing a few additional mechanics to keep things interesting.

Unless you are the type who gets motion sick from VR games that most are completely fine with, I doubt you need to worry about motion sickness. Although on rare occasions, you may be thrown a little off balance for a split-second. If you play in a tight space, it would also probably be good idea to have the headset's Chaparone setting turned on, as you can easily stray a little from the center of your area and reach outside of your play area without realizing.

In terms of replay value, that really depends on you. If you are the type to just go through once and never look back, the game's 30 levels will probably only last you a few hours. If you are more of a completionist, you will get much more out of it. There are medals to earn for faster times and getting through more challenging hidden paths. There will also be multiplayer races in the future. Hopefully we will also see more levels in the furture too.

The are a couple of trivial things that could be improved. The game's menus are extremely bland. The environments, although certainly posessing a sense of style and diversity, don't offer much in the way of eye-candy. And while the game has some great songs, it is a short playlist. But at the end of the day, core gameplay matters more than superficial asthetics, and To The Top is proof of that.

This delightfully genre-diverse toe tapper excites me in ways that I haven't felt from a game tracked by various artists since Katamari Damacy. 32229202.review:
This game is $25 but fucking hell it's worth it. Imagine Assassins Creed in 1st Person, climbing to the peak of a level and overlooking your challenges and the entire map, but you know, not boring and repetitive, it's actually fun.

The screen shots and videos don't do the visuals justice. In VR, it is sometimes distracting how great everything looks, it's not one of those blurry, jaggy VR games heavily relying on lots of fancy textures.

This game starts as a simple "grab the blue objects to climb" experience, that gradually transforms into this grand, exuberant mess of exhilaration that I haven't experienced in any other game. The mechanics are simple enough and requires no force to jump distances. Instead you learn to time subsequent jumps like in Super Mario 64 which propels you further along the direction you are looking. You don't need to move your arms but I do it anyway because it creates this really primal feeling I haven't experienced in any other game, it's like being a predator in the jungle, or Mufasa leaping from rock to rock, and even falling feels fucking incredible and gets your heart pumping.

Even collecting the gems/jewel/crystals things in the game is fun, because it is challenging and you have to think about how you are going to get to certain location and sometimes time your movements, like having to wait for the perfect moment to free fall off of a giant that is moving in order to reach that one last crystal thing you need to unlock the next level, that you know is going to have more cool ass shit you didn't expect.

Don't miss out on this release if you are at all interested in some exhilarating 1st person Parkour Platforming with huge jumps, skating, sky diving, and more (I haven't finished the game but read that there is some rockets boosters and other cool stuff to be unlocked).

I've included a link to a video of me attempting to break the current top score in the Giant Robot Level (which I didn't, but I did reach a personal best by subtracting 10 seconds to my lowest time)

https://youtu.be/f-1yX_ACoCY

I feel like my first review really didn't do justice to this game.

The further you progress in this game, the better it gets! The medium levels are much better than the easy ones and the hard ones even exceed the medium ones!

You shouldn't buy this game considering it a climbing game like Climbey. It is more about leaping and reminds me of some old school 3d platformers like Mario 64 at times (especially when it comes to the collecting aspect).
I love the variety of challenges it provides (speedrunning to get medals or exploring the levels to find hidden ones) and how it keeps introducing new gameplay elements even during the last few levels.

I'd love to see some DLC or even more so a sequel in the future.

Do yourself a favor and give this game a chance, even if you're not blown away at first. At least keep playing until you get to the medium levels.

From the comfort side, it's a winner: it's safe to play with a very affordable comfort level. Even contents are on par (if not over) my expectations: multiple levels full of alternate paths and secrets.

Unfortunately the control method used is just not fun, and break any involvment or realism. It's good from the gameplay side, has a learning curve and after a while (it's not intuitive at his very start) you're jumping everywhere. But it's just unacceptable for me than in a roomscale VR game when you can't grab virtual items: here you have laser pointers on your hand, if a blue surface is in your range you shoot with trigger and you're there. You're not going to sweat, to lean, to move arms trying to reach an handle. I tried to trick my mind thinking "you're like Spiderman, that point and click pointers could be webs, have fun!" but at the end of the day I hated it, it's a step in the wrong direction than reminds me the untracked VR era.

To The Top just now has 40/40 positive ratings, so even if I consider this game worthy I'm respectfully leaving a negative review sure than this won't be so bad for his overall reputation. It's a good platformer in the tradition of Windlands but if you're searching for a climbing game, you could be disappointed.

31948811.review:
They weren't kidding in the trailer when they put that big, gratuitous FREEDOM. OF. MOVEMENT. 

Seriously, I feel more free playing this game than in any other VR game, and I get around pretty well. It feels somewhere between TF2 jump maps and Climbey, with the aesthetic of Mirror's Edge. 

To The Top trades a lack of accuracy in technical climbing for an exhilarating, leaping, spider man crossed with the hulk crossed with Mirror's Edge experience. You run across the ground, fling yourself into the air, swing from buildings, and glide across roofs. It's a feeling I've been chasing in skill-based movement games since I started to get the itch for this kind of thing. Already set a WR on a map, I'm ready to tackle more!

I like just about everything in this game. Here's what I DON'T like:

- Handling of relative motion is not completely consistent. Some moving obstacles, while you're attached to them, seem static, and if you jump at the wrong angle, they kill you. Collision damage should be based on relative speed, not absolute.

- The skate mechanic can be infuriating. In some spots, it's faster to spam grab your way across gaps than to actually skate.

- No workshop map support! This game is missing out bigtime on that front.

- Not enough flying levels. The flying implementation in this game is fantastic, but it's not fleshed out whatsoever. It's a huge loss that the climbing element and the flying are barely integrated.

And that's pretty much it. Two of them aren't actually issues, they're just me wanting more. None of them are reasons not to buy the game.

31940406.review:
Must buy! I've only had a couple of hours in this game so far but it's been a blast!

If you are worried about motion sickness, somehow it's very minimal in this game. Even though it doesn't blur vision or narrow the field of view during movement, I don't feel an ounce of nausea. I think the biggest reason for this is one of the gameplay mechanics: you look where you leap. I.e. you will always move in the direction you look.

This means you cannot jump backwards, or sideways. And you also have significant air control (you can change direction mid-air) by looking where you want to go.

So because of this, you will always be moving "forward" relative to the direction you're facing, which is the least likely to induce nausea.

Of course, I cannot speak for everyone when I say it won't cause nausea. Your best bet is to try it out for yourself.

The way you move around is probably the most fun I've had in a VR game in a long time. Now I want other games with this movement scheme! If there is ever a VR Spiderman game, this is where it's at!

Also: you can be as active as you want while playing. You can swing your arms together like a squirrel bounding between tree branches, or you can simply press and release the triggers while looking in the direction you want to jump. It's very accessible for people have limited space, or can't move their arms for long periods of time.

Speaking of accessibility, I'm hoping the developers can add an option to snap-turn in increments for players unable to stand up while playing. Just a thought.

Altogether, amazing game and one of the best recent releases for VR!

31911904.review:
This is an absoulte must-buy for VR (as long as you're not super-sensitive to VR sickness).  I haven't had this much fun with a VR game since I first got the headset over a year ago.  No other game lets you fly through the air at these speeds, with just the right amount of control and finesse.  It's an amazing VR platformer, with nice visuals, great feeling controls, really chill music, and enough content to warrent the price.  

Right now, I have about 2 hours in, and I've done about 1/3 of the levels (getting 100% completion in them).  Given that the later levels are likely harder and will take more time, I'd be very suprised if I am done before the 6 hour mark.  I'd imagine most people would take a bit longer than that if they are 100% completing every level.  I'm also really looking forward to playing this game constantly.

There are going to be inevitable comparisons to Climbey.  They are very different games.  TTT is focused on moving fast, doing huge jumps, and flying through the air.  Climbey is more focused on climbing, and you don't ever really get the speeds you get in TTT.  The fact that this game has released with a large number of actually designed levels that have secrets, collectibles, time trials, and tons of level features makes this game win over Climbey any day of the week.  Yes, Climbey has multiplayer and a level editor, but the core levels that come with it aren't very good, and last only an hour or so.  I also don't really want to sift through the thousands of crappy user-created levels to find the best ones.  TTT has far more enjoyable content, and feels a lot more polished.  

I recommend the crap out of this game.

31911642.review:
《超越(To The Top)》是一款特别的攀爬跳跃类VR游戏，游戏中你将超越超现实的环境，并且在这款最新的VR游戏中发现全新的挑战!这将是一场有趣而引人入胜的体验!

　　其实说到攀爬类的游戏，我们也没少体验，不过通常游戏都会在其中增加一些别的元素，让过程不至于显得无聊。比如《攀登》的重点似乎是放在了游戏场景的建模上，让玩家欣赏几乎可以以假乱真的风景或许才是游戏的本意。

　　《超越》的玩法呢跟一般的攀岩游戏一样，玩家需要通过自己的双手在各种奇怪的地势上攀爬或跳跃。不过游戏还增加了一个远距离定点瞬移的功能，用于距离过远的移动，因为在游戏中玩家除了攀登以外并不能在地面行走。

　　游戏有个特别的机制，一般来说攀岩这个项目主要是求稳的，并不会在乎时间这个问题，但在《超越》中玩家们却需要考虑自己的攀爬时间了。游戏采用了计时的机制，最后成绩会出现在重点的大屏幕上，与世界玩家进行对比，这样的设计是不是很能激发玩家的斗志。

　　玩家们不用担心游戏内容不够，目前游戏准备了30几个地图供玩家挑战，并且都是格局、难度不一样的场地，连画风都是各种各样的，一定不会让玩家觉得游戏难度不足，或是单一的场景造成的审美疲劳。

　　游戏的难度不完全在于攀爬的技巧，更重要的是随着后期地形越来越复杂，玩家们不仅要考虑怎么稳稳地爬到终点，还要计划攀登的路线。游戏不仅仅是只要到达终点就够了，还会不断增加道具获取等玩法，所以一条能够顺利获得所有道具并到达终点的路线也是很重要的。

　　游戏不单单是需要玩家们的操作技巧，还需要开动脑筋，配合眼睛和手进行游戏的挑战。这样眼手脑相互结合的游戏，感觉比较适合有活力的年轻人玩，同时也可以跟朋友比比看谁比较厉害。

　　虽然游戏可以满足部分玩家对攀岩的好奇，但《超越》的攀登方式却并不贴近现实。游戏本身的设定就是玩家操作未来超级机器人进行攀登的，所以机械化的攀登必然就比较超现实了，与现实中徒手攀岩的感觉截然不同。

　　游戏的攀登方式有些独特了，虽然操着一双机械手臂，但攀爬时可以发射出虚拟的手掌，抓住不远处的墙壁，玩家就能顺着方向移动过去了。看来看去都觉得这招跟蜘蛛侠发射蜘蛛丝来移动的方式很像啊，不过游戏相对“粗暴”一点，直接就把手掌射出去了。

　　至于跳跃嘛，玩家只要双手在同一处，使劲向要去的方向甩动手柄再松手，就可以顺利跃向要去的地方，最后只要及时抓住那边的墙壁就好了。虽然这种攀登方式有点“作弊”嫌疑，但考虑到难度，游戏还是设置了范围的限制，避免玩家们一步登天。

　　另外，游戏还是很遵循攀岩的基本属性。游戏场景中不是所有墙面都可以任意攀爬的，跟现实中的攀岩游戏一样，游戏中也只有各种形状的蓝色凸出部分才可以抓，也给游戏增加了一些难度。

　　对于攀岩游戏来说，游戏“蜘蛛侠”式的抓取操作以及机器人逆天的跳跃能力，确实让游戏难度有些许减弱，但好在游戏场景的难度设计填补了这方面的体验。不过回头想想游戏未来世界的设定，以及时间机制的设计，或许这种操作形态才比较合适吧。

　　由于计时机制的促使，游戏俨然变成了一种款节奏的状态，使得玩家开始游戏后都会有些紧张，然后就容易操作失误了。

　　游戏考验着玩家操作的速度和精准度，以及观察力和快速判断的能力。可能这么说玩家们会觉得有些夸张，但你真在游戏中的时候们就能体会到我现在说的这些了。

　　对于观察力和判断力，从开始游戏时考验就开始了。后期慢慢复杂的地形中，考虑到时间大家肯定会快速地冲出去，而这时需要判断道具和终点的位置，快速决定要走的路，不能慌不择路，那样会很耽误时间。

　　操作的精确和快速就更不用说，因为一旦失误就有可能会耽误很多时间，所以路线和操作这两样是游戏必须注意的终点。游戏说难也不难，说简单却也不简单，看着排行榜上有些令人不可思议的时间，你会忍不住想要挑战的。

　　游戏操作反馈也是值得称赞的地方，虽然力度不是很大，但每一个动作的反馈都很到位，能够及时判断出自己的操作是否到位，使得游戏操作准确度大大提升，减少不必要的失误。

　　游戏体验非常有意思，内容上也十分完整，唯一一点不足就是不适合长时间体验，画面有时会出现掉帧情况，导致玩家产生晕眩感，不过不会特别严重。游戏攀爬跳跃的方式虽然超现实，但操作效果却很顺畅，虽然与现实有一定出入，但放在游戏中的体验还是很新颖的。

　　目前《超越(To The Top)》在steam上的售价78元。游戏场景多变且内容充足，计时的游戏机制特别适合喜欢挑战的玩家，这类动手量较大的游戏也很适合喜欢动作游戏的玩家，虽然价格有些偏贵，还是推荐喜欢的玩家们购买体验。

31906258.review:
To The Top is one of the most enjoyable games I have played in Virtual Reality.  Have had the game for a while as a pre release and have had the pleasure of seeing levels and features added.

Level design is in a way where new gameplay elements are added in a manner that is  very intuitive.  At the beginning a tutorial explains the basic features on how to maneuver, and then lets you loose.  On each level a new gameplay element is added, moving surfaces, breakaway handholds, and they are all color coded so it is easy to tell at a glance.

The art style of the game is stylized so it is easy to tell where your handholds and grab points are.  If you are running the courses for speed, it makes it easy to find your next point at a glance.  

Each level have items called Geoms that add an exploration factor as well, makes climbing around off the beaten path rewarding and find some nice hidden areas.  You will be challenged with gaps to get across and even natural hazards like lava.
The soundtrack is awesome and fits the game very well, very energetic music that goes along with what is happening.

An example of one of the quality of life features that the developers of To The Top have thought about that so many others gloss over is the difference between their Vibe development platform and the Oculus.  The natural hand position for the Vibe controllers and the Touch controllers is off by a few degrees, but we are given options to fine tune the angle of the hands to feel more natural.  Everyone else needs to take note of this.. THIS is how you do it.

For those that are having motion sickness, make sure to check out the grid option, it gives a grid effect that appears around you when moving fast that helps the user be able to keep their orientation and will reduce any illness

31896621.review:
Amazing game. Usually when I see a lesser known VR game that intrigues me on steam I wait a while to see how many reviews it gets and if they are positive. Either that or until it starts to get a lot of buzz on reddit. I decided to grab this , because it had caught my attention several times since it was released a few days ago in the new releases tab. It looked like a ton of fun.

I am so glad I decided to grab it. This game is a little different than I thought it would be I thought you would have to swing your arms and pull yourself to each platform. The control scheme works different than that though, you use your hands to grab and position within your view, and your head to control the direction you jump / fly in. I suspect this is how they reduced nausea despite the fact that this is a very fast paced title. Its an amazing interpretation of a platformer in VR. The control scheme and locomotion is not something I would consider as hampering the game even though it was different than I thought it would be, unlike some titles where you wish the locomotion/ control schemes didnt get bogged down by the developers trying to illeviate motion sickness I did not feel that with this game.

The game itself has a good amount of Content over 30 levels I believe and tons of replayability. You will certainly not master these levels on your first play through. There are secret routes you can take and collectibles on each level not to mention level times , which is where I think most of my replayability will come in, trying to complete levels as fast as I can to not only get medals for faster completions (which unlock new levels) but hopefully to compete on leaderboards. I will attest that I did not notice any leaderboards on my playthrough of the first 14 levels but if they are not there I imagine it is something that will be added when the Dev adds multiplayer in the future (something they have said they will do)

This game is not climbey, it is much more fast paced. Its more like a parkour game with jetpacks. Highly suggest it for almost anyone. I am generally not into these types of games as much but this one intrigued me enough to give it a try, and I dont regret it.

Edit: I have a few criticisms though after playing a little while longer. During my first play through I was happy to go from level to level just trying every level out, but now for example if I dont get the right time on a level there doesnt seem to be a menu option once your actually in the game. To either restart the level or to go back to the main menu. Your actually kind of stuck in the infinite loop of going level to level until you decide to quit the game and restart it to get back to the main menu as far as I can tell. I have pressed every button on the controllers to no avail when it comes to finding a menu. This seems like a serious design flaw, in a game where posting fast times is important either resetting mid level if you screw up to many times or even deciding to replay the level if you JUST missed the time you wanted would be important features., and they are missing from TO THE TOP. I still recommend this game, but TBH the lack of this feature alone put a pretty big damper on my experience.

Oh my god... Where do I even begin? 
I've certainly never played anyting like it. In a VR landscape littered with shooting galleries, To The Top feels genuinely unique.

It feels like you're in a giant virtual jungle gym! Getting some speed up by launching yourself off different objects is super fun and the sense of scale is really something. Looking up to see your end point miles above you and realising you'll soon be up there is incredible.

31848677.review:
This is a very fun platforming game. There are over 30 levels with a varity of themes and mechanics. You unlock levels by getting medals. you get three by beating different times, 1 from collecting all the geoms and one from getting a hidden one usually much more difficult to find and get to. Levels start easy but the game does ramp up in difficulty with timing and hazards in the later levels. 

This is much more of a jumping parkour platforming game then a climbing so don't go in expecting super realistic climbing your jump direction and movement in the air is based on where you are looking which is weird at first but becomes very intuitive after a bit. The game has a fairly simple style but still looks good, music is good but limited so can start to get old after hearing the same songs 10+ times while playing the game.

You can easy get your value trying to beat the built in and leaderboard times and finding the collectibles.

The devs have talked about plans for more maps, and game modes possibly including some arena multiplayer type things.

As it the game is absolutly worth 25 bucks and while I got the game for free I bought the game to give to someone just to support the devs

Simplement a prendre les yeux fermés !

31846429.review: 100% recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of VR and platforming games. The puzzles and levels are well designed, the game mechanics are unique and fun and as someone who is susceptible to motion sickness in certain VR titles, I so far have experienced none whatsoever. Really looking forward to seeing this title evolve and hopefully one day allow steam workshop levels for the community to create even more awesome levels for us to jump and climb through!

31844322.review:
I've never wanted to go to bed sooner so I could wake up with the energy to play a video game... Until now, of course.

Won this in a giveaway, but I think I would have bought it regardless, the soundtrack, the quick "juicy" movement, it all feels so good.

Moving is kinda weird at first but once you get used to it you can start easily chaining jumps to reach mach speeds, it's amazing.

The level design is great too, levels start out by introducing you to new mechanics that the level then takes full advantage of, whilst fitting the overall theme of the level (I.E, ziplines in a giant city level) then new levels will take these mechanics and ramp up the difficulty with them (see the 25 second mark of the trailer for a good example of this).

Did I mention the soundtrack? Oh yeah, I did, well not enough, it's great, I'll be coming back to play this just for the soundtrack, it includes awesome songs like Vireo's Eye by Future Islands. They all just fit the feeling of "flying" this game gives you.

Now, because I've only played an hour so far, I can't comment on later levels & mechanics, so I'll update this when I get some more time in and try everything out, but so far the amount of content and fun this game offers is well worth its asking price of $24.99 USD.

UPDATE: Holy shit this game gets intense later on, moving platforms, timed jumps, boost pads, skating, puzzles.

31840892.review: fast and fun, if you like first person platformers this is a must have

31837135.review:
（2017-5-20更新：昨天玩了后，今天手臂竟然酸疼了，第一次玩Climbey时也曾经酸疼过，自问已经在Climbey身经百战了，没想到玩这个竟然又玩到酸疼了...）

作为攀爬（跑酷）类VR游戏，有Climbey珠玉在前，之后出的类似游戏基本上都“全军覆没”，想凑10个好评都不容易。这个游戏又是定价78元，远超Climbey价格，看这游戏开发了一年多，真是替开发商担心没人买，决定看看有什么底气敢定价这么高。

这游戏跟Climbey一样操作都很简单，主要是通过关卡的设计来展现出玩法的多样性，简单但不单调。没有瞬移、平移等地面移动方式，只能通过那些抓取点移动和甩手臂飞跃，正是因为这个设计，导致感觉完全不同，类型相似，却是另外一种风格，不能在地面平移确保你要尽量不停地飞跃，很有超级英雄（蜘蛛侠）的感觉。

缺点就是那双手，按一下键，双手就射向抓取点，感觉太唐突了，如果换成另一个看起来更自然的东西或有什么连接手就更好了。这双手可能需要时间习惯一下，习惯之后倒是没觉得有何不妥，但新手如果没玩多久，一开始不习惯可能会影响玩下去的兴致。还有会让人误会这游戏只是点击一下就能移动，我本来有点怕买这个游戏就是因为这双手。

音乐、画面等都看得出确实是一个打磨了很久的游戏，关卡和造型丰富，玩10个小时或以上应该不是问题，还有多人模式（暂时没开放），希望以后能支持创意工坊，那通关后也有得玩了。恐高慎入之外，我强烈推荐这游戏，但不要期望跟Climbey一样，一样的话也没必要买这么贵的了。

31833717.review:
Really a fantastic game. I had some pains early on because I don't follow instructions well, but despite not being crazy into climbing VR games I think it's one of the best VR games available right now (full stop). It doesn't skimp on anything.

Video review available here: https://youtu.be/ukeAmPB1HY4

Pros:
Gameplay is skill-based, easy to pick up, addictive.
Great visuals and sounds.
Music is really great.
Very varied environments.
Lots of gameplay.
Devs description of the game is very accurate for once.
Post-release updates coming, no Early Access - just free content.
Motion sickness is low.

Cons:
Movement style may not be the most natural, but it is intuitive and I think better than just swinging your arms. (not really a con).
Really struggling to think of cons. If more VR games were of this quality... well I'd spend more time in VR.

31833057.review:
WOW! What a rush!

This game is AMAZINGLY good, like the VR version of Mirror's Edge in many ways. The way the grabbing system works is a little less realistic but its very intuitive for doing super-fast speed hops from one surface to another. Speed builds up as you successfully hop multiple times and when coupled with surfaces that can effect the way you move it can allow you to build yourself up and .. just .. FLY!

The level design is also something to be admired. Each level has a certain amount of "Geoms" you have to collect which make for cool challenge points requiring you to really observe the level and use the terrain in many fun and interest ways in order to collect them. There is also a Hidden "geom" in each level which are SO rewarding to find and often very challenging to reach.

After about an hour's play I have so far only unlocked about a 3rd of the game so I feel like, so far at least, there is plenty of longevity although as I get better at the game I might end up breezing through it. However the existence of Hidden geoms and requiring to collect all the geoms in the game will make for a much lengthier experience overall. 

Plus, the game is just FUN, like I would come back to any one of these levels just to feel the rush of certain mechanics of each level. I could easily see myself spending 10 hours plus in this game. Seriously if you started playing this game and you're thinking "meh" .. JUST GET TO THE LEVEL WITH THE FREAKING HALF-PIPES... HOLY SHIT!

Update: 10 Hours ..... HAH!

Also as an Oculus Rift user ,SteamVR generally runs very poorly for me. To the Top only supports SteamVR currently but due to the low-fidelity of the graphics it doesnt seem to effect me too much, I have had near 0 frame frops, judder or tracking loss. On top of that, the Dev's went the extra mile to add a Controller tilt/rotate option to the options menu which allowed me to get the hands feeling more or less the way they should on the Touch Controllers. +10 Dev points for that, excellent fore-sight while they work on the proper Oculus Version for Oculus Home.

Update 2: As of the latest version, Oculus is now natively supported by the game. It also added 5 new levels and multiplayer. Definitely get in on this if you haven't already.

Overall, DONT miss this game .. I 100% recommend it. Must BUY!

31829764.review: I do NOT recommend this game as is because of the disappointing controls but everything else about it is pristine so I feel obligated to mark it recommended. The visuals are crystal clear and will completely drown out all sense of the real world and there’s plenty of levels with hopefully the promise of multiplayer implementation, as seen in the menu, but are highly repayable as they are.  If you’ve ever played “The Climb” or “Climbey” however, you’re going to be very disappointed with this game.  The controls are point and click and not immersive at all.  Please dev, I know this is a huge design change but I really don’t feel like playing this game any further, which is a huge disappointment for a broke college student on a $25 purchase.  Especially sense that’s the only thing wrong with it!

39597125.review:
I don't like heights, and when I say that I mean "I don't like ladders taller than myself" afraid of heights.

This is probably one of the first... moments in my life I've slip into the entertainment of something and let that fear go away. By all accounts, hanging from the side of a crane with nothing but a long fall below me should be causing cold chills, and it hardly even bothers me in this game.. 

The controls are fluid, and scream for speed running. The two forms of movement are "monkey bars" style hand-over-hand and double-handed leaping. Each has it's moments, but leaping accross ledges, off objects, and ever upwards is incredibly satisfying. The game even rewards you for your speed and precision with "momentum" which can take an obstacle that would take a long time to climb into a few solid leaps.

Easy to understand, easier to play, but enough challange to make me want more.
